references.paper_title: Supervised learning in spiking neural networks with force training
references.reason: This paper demonstrates that stable high-dimensional time signals can improve network performance on sequential motor tasks, a concept relevant to the current study's focus on sequence generation.

references.paper_title: Meta-Learning through Hebbian Plasticity in Random Networks
references.reason: This paper explores the use of Hebbian plasticity for meta-learning, a technique also employed in the current study to discover self-organized sequence-generating plasticity rules.

references.paper_title: Neural Circuit Architectural Priors for Embodied Control
references.reason: This paper investigates how architectural priors can improve the sample efficiency and generalization of reinforcement learning approaches to locomotion, a concept relevant to the study's focus on self-organization.
This paper introduces the concept of meta-learning in reinforcement learning, which is relevant to the current study's approach of using meta-learning to discover plasticity rules.

references.paper_title: A Scalable Population Code for Time in the Striatum
references.reason: This paper presents a model of time representation in the striatum that is relevant to the current study's investigation of sequence-generating neural circuits.
